ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Solid overview of American naval history. Very much a survey course. Very little discussion of motivation, themes, etc beyond the operational level.

I learned about intellectual thought related to the navy, such as Just War Theory, Mahanian naval theory, and grand strategy. We discussed the application of these ideas to the actions taken by our armed forces. We also discussed how Yale and Yale students have been involved with the navy and served and sacrificed in multiple wars. Furthermore, we learned the history of our navy and how the navy enforced American strategies both in peacetime and war time. We delivered presentations and had discussions about these themes.
A good introduction to an overview of US history with a focus on the Navys impact and changing strategy over time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Add more discussion from primary sources, like a history class. This could be a fantastic history seminar while still fulfilling the navy's needs.

My favorite part of this course was discussing ideas such as Just War Theory, hearing from JL Gaddis about grand strategy, and learning about Mahan. Sometimes I got lost in the history because I'm not familiar with technical naval terminology, but that was prerequisite information that I should've learned on my own. Maybe a navy-kowledge-101 packet would've been helpful to start.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student interested in naval history and war theories, grand strategy, etc.. You have to be wiling to do the reading to learn and be able to do some thick historical readings. The context of knowing the navy (ie. naval technical terminology) can add a small but manageable challenge, and sometimes learning the details of battles isn't exciting (though it really depends on your interests). However, the class itself isn't hard at all if you put in some effort and approach it with a positive attitude. We also did a joint class with Air Force ROTC led by John Lewis Gaddis, who is a legend. Capt. Withrow himself is wonderful - he is kind, understanding, positive, and helpful. Plus, taking a course with Yale's NROTC midshipmen is both an honor and a pleasure! The perspective I gained here was unmatched. I had a blast.
Any student outside of NROTC with an interest in the military would enjoy this class.
